summary: The documents suggest that 'Washington (EUR/BNL)' was a recipient of intelligence reports from Brussels concerning the 'Flemish Order of Militants' (VMO - Vlaamse Militanten Orde). The documents indicate that Washington sought information on the VMO, possibly through the House Committee on Assassinations. NITRUST, a liaison contact, was reluctant to share information due to Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) concerns. Ultimately, NIGALE declined to prepare a report on the VMO for the House of Representatives Committee, citing a lack of information on VMO-American citizen contacts between 1968 and 1970. The documents span from May 5, 1978, to May 19, 1978, indicating a concentrated period of inquiry regarding the VMO.
key_connections: Flemish Order of Militants (VMO - Vlaamse Militanten Orde)
significance: The significance of Washington (EUR/BNL) lies in its apparent interest in the Vlaamse Militanten Orde (VMO) and its potential connection to the House Committee on Assassinations' investigation. The reluctance of NITRUST to share information and NIGALE's ultimate refusal to prepare a report suggest a sensitivity around the VMO and its possible links to American citizens, potentially relevant to the JFK assassination investigation, although the exact nature of the connection remains unclear from these documents alone.
